content: REVOLVING FUND. The United States Institute for Environmental Conflict Resolution Revolving Fund is established in the Treasury, administered by the Foundation. The Fund is used for operating the Institute, including salaries, mediation services, and other necessary expenses. It is separate from the Trust Fund and not subject to certain program priorities. The Secretary of the Treasury invests portions of the Fund not needed for current expenses. The United States Institute for Environmental Conflict Resolution Revolving Fund is established in the Treasury and administered by the Foundation. The Fund is used for operating the Institute, including salaries, mediation services, and other necessary expenses. The Secretary of the Treasury invests portions of the Fund not needed for current expenses in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. Investments can be made on original issue at the issue price or by purchasing outstanding obligations at the market price. Any obligations acquired by the Revolving Fund may be sold by the Secretary of the Treasury at the market price, with interest and proceeds from sales or redemptions credited to the Fund. The Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence in National Environmental and Native American Public Policy Act of 1992 is amended to include a new section allowing the use of the Institute by a federal agency. The Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence in National Environmental and Native American Public Policy Act of 1992 is amended to authorize federal agencies to utilize the Foundation and the Institute for assessment, mediation, or related services in environmental, public lands, or natural resources disputes. Federal agencies can contract and pay for Institute services, with payments going into a Revolving Fund. Agencies must notify the chairperson of the President's Council on Environmental Quality before using the Foundation or Institute, providing details on the issues, parties involved, and prior efforts. Federal agencies must obtain the concurrence of the chairperson of the President's Council on Environmental Quality before using the Foundation or Institute for services in disputes involving multiple agencies or instrumentalities of the Federal Government. This includes providing details on the issues, parties involved, and prior resolution efforts. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations for the Trust Fund and Revolving Fund, with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 1998 to 2002. SEC. 9. Conforming amendments. SEC. 9 of the Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence Act makes amendments to replace "Fund" with "Trust Fund" in various sections of the Act.
